title: Who will be selected as the next leader of Germany's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) party at its special party congress?
possible_answers: No successor will be selected at the special party congress or the special party congress will be canceled
correct_answer: No successor will be selected at the special party congress or the special party congress will be canceled
preds:
A. Kramp-Karrenbauer could just be confirmed and/or re-elected, which in the possible answers would be the "someone else" answer: the pressure on her party CDU has somewhat lifted, since the SARS-CoV-2 response and its success has been solely assigned to Mrs. Merkel and her CDU. She just repeatedly stressed, that under no circumstance will she once more apply for a seat in parliament nor being elected chancellor. The need for a re-orientation after 15+ years under Merkel's leadership will remain, more so as general elections are scheduled for 2021. However, discussions and eventualities brought forward now concerning the future personnel could harm the current impression of unity within CDU/CSU, and a constructive quietude.
Unless she makes bigger mistakes as the party leader or will leave more negative impressions of her work as minister of defence, A. Kramp-Karrenbauer will be confirmed in her position for the sake of peace within the party.
It seems the congress had been "cancelled" for that date in December in the meantime (or rather put on stand by, I would say), but that @pstamp does not exclude for the next weeks and months, that the same special congress will be re-scheduled to e.g. September when large gatherings with 1,000 participants or more are likely to be admitted again. Circumstances due to the pandemic change fast this year, and it looks as if political processes have started rolling again now.
 I would rather read the last answer as "No successor will be selected at the special party congress or there will be no special party congress before 1 Jan 2021 happening". Therefore, no early resolution possible before 31 Dec 2020.

No resolution by GJO even with the third source provided. Shared the best of them here, but almost nobody listened. Well, I´ll just forget about this question and wait till it ends in my favor. Will be nice for me anyway, getting better scores every day this is still active.
Next resolution attempt with this link: https://www.hz.de/politik/cdu-ein-parteitag_-viele-szenarien-46529634.html

Asked for resolution. Both links are in german, I didn´t find an english one, sorry (short summary: special congress cancelled; they will decide it on the regular party congress in december): https://www.merkur.de/politik/coronavirus-cdu-akk-nachfolger-sonderparteitag-abgesagt-friedrich-merz-armin-laschet-norbert-roettgen-zr-13774119.html https://www.cdu.de/calendar/month/2020-12/15596%2B17
Attempting to incorporate the detailed comments of @pstamp regarding the state of CDU/CSU politics and not be caught flat footed if things change. Who knew?

@bobrown
Sorry for not having explained the last radical move yet. The background is similar to my post on 21 April:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1018969
It´s not the first part of that (you´re right about that contradicting opening football) but the second. As a result of very popular crisis management Söder (CSU) will most probably be the candidate of CDU and CSU together for German chancellor after Merkel. 
1) The job of party leader of the CDU is only attractive for the candidates, if they have a chance to get chancellor. The candidates with best chances to get elected (Laschet and Merz) would have nothing to gain from "just being party leader" without a perspective for more. Much work, little income, little real power. They could only loose.
2) Current leader Kramp-Karrenbauer is in a much better position now than she was a few months ago, so there is no urgent need to replace her.
3) As AKK and others announced, the population would not understand a public power struggle in times of crisis. That´s very true. The mainly left-wing german media would hang them for that. The next regular party congress is scheduled for early December (3rd-5th). A special congress could happen only shortly before that (argument: cancellation of Oktoberfest) so it makes no sense regarding the above mentioned reasons. None of the candidates or the party leadership is even talking about it. It won´t happen. I think, this question will resolve on 3rd December or earlier as "special party congress cancelled". 100% might be too much, of course, your current position is very clever strategically, can be adapted to all changes without having lost much. It just felt cool to go all in for me.
I'll try to follow the zig zags of @pstamp even without commentary. If they are playing football, why wouldn't they hold a party congress?

Laschet is Primeminister of NRW in Germany, that gives him some advantage in public judgement. But none of the known candidates so far can match with Angela Merkel. Her awareness of power is to big to left her house unprepeared and without care.

Given that German is slowly opening, there may not be an OctoberFest, but there most likely be Party Congress, even if it over Zoom. If they are playing football this fall, then why not have a congress?

The CDU poll reported in this seems the best start point https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-05/merkel-critic-leads-loyalist-in-cdu-race-according-to-poll .  I've bumped Laschet up slightly and Merz down slightly due to Laschet's visibility during Covid, but I doubt it'll make much long term difference.  Current markets (SMarket and Betfair) still have Merz as the frontrunner.  I think it's unlikely there'll be no leader going into 2021 given that's the year of the next election; also Germany seems pretty willing to unlock.

This is a decision about the future path of the CDU. A move to the right, or more of the status quo. Rottgen is very much an outsider and at this stage has a minimal chance of becoming the leader. Merz very narrowly lost to Kramp-Karrenbauer in 2018. And is currently polling as the favourite amongst CDU supporters and the wider population.[1] Laschet’s chances increased following Spahn's backing. His approval ratings have increased during the COVID-19 crisis. But seems to be lagging behind Metz at this stage. There is a chance of cancellation due to the pandemic. However, there will likely be a period of time when a decision can be made before 1 Jan 2021. The question has already extended the time limit due to a cancellation. However, I doubt this will happen again. Criticism is very welcome! https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-05/merkel-critic-leads-loyalist-in-cdu-race-according-to-poll
Not clear how the congress will be held, but a new leader is needed.

Base rates were based on Google News search hits in the last year, in which Laschet has 63,000 results (61.5%), Merz has 21,800 results (21.2%), and Röttgen has 17,600 results (17.1%). Other investigated candidates (Braun, Schuster, Glave, Karliczek) do not get enough media attention to warrant competition to Röttgen individually, but combined (~15,000 results) make may for an unlikely dark horse.
Total cancellation of the party congress seems unlikely, since a successor to Kramp-Karrenbauer needs to be found regardless of pandemics, though no hard numbers were used for this hunch. Laschet/Spahn are gaining popularity fast amidst the Covid-19 Pandemic (https://www.euractiv.com/section/politics/news/covid-19-crisis-boosts-support-for-laschet-spahn-in-cdu-leadership-race/). Merz has recently gotten negative publicity for slamming Italy's response to the pandemic, whereas Röttgen is portrayed as pro-EU in recent news publications.
Merkel will become chairman ones again. The former Chancellors all had to be forced out, they didnt quit on their own. It will be the same here.
Hattip @pstamp for reminding me that Oktoberfest was cancelled and this puts other large gatherings on notice.
A newcomer against an experienced with a controversial image

If they cancel Oktoberfest, there will most likely be no special party congress before October. Until 31 August it´s forbidden, and nobody would understand, how they could cancel one indoor mass gathering but hold another themselves. And there are other things more important now than choosing a new party leader, with AKK still in Office (and in a much better position than before her announcement to resign) and the question who will be candidate for chancellor more open than ever. Söder just scores big in the corona crisis, and he´s not CDU but CSU, which would mean choosing a CDU Party leader with little chance of getting Chancellor. Makes no sense to hold a special party congress for that in times of crisis.
as incumbent prime minister, Laschet has the best chance of an election

Merz has lost to Annegret Kramp Karrenbauer, a rather weak candidate, in the last bid for presidency of the CDU, and that said a lot already. He does not have enough mass appeal to beat Laschet nor did he hold any political office nor did he ever front-run a campaign. The only thing that could happen is that the three candidates from North Rhine Westphalia (Laschet, Merz, Röttgen) divide the West German votes so that some candidate from Eastern Germany or Northern Germany might finally sneak to the top.

Before the Corona crisis, my top candidate was Friedriech Merz (50 - 60 %). Due to the Corona crisis the balance of power has shifted.
In my eyes it will be either Armin Laschet or Markus Soeder, depending on how the Corona crisis ends

Due to the pandemic all the unlikely events become way more likely. "Someone else" and "No successor" both are big classes of unlikely events. These small probabilities add up quite a bit in this situation.
Markus Söder should have a good chance.
Bavaria's Minister President Markus Soeder (CSU- Christian Socialist Union- Bavaria's "sister party" of Merkel's CDU) just might "supersize" his way to the top.
Fiddling with the numbers on no data.

I just got the invitation to attend a nationwide meeting end of August by our biggest insurance company. The first invitation after countless cancellations, and insurance companies know how to calculate risks. This will happen before october, and it will be Laschet who wins.

Laschet a little weakened because of low profile in the crisis. Merz recovered from infection but in no good position/office to score at the moment. Same with Röttgen: no profile at all in the crisis. Spahn ("someone else") strengthened for good crisis management as Health Minister - but he told publicly to be Laschets wingman as CDU leaders. Would loose credibility, if he changed that now and wouldn´t have the same backing in the party alone as Laschet. They are the perfect team. Only reasonable way to go as such. CDU still needs a new leader. Holding such an event will be possible in the next few months (laaaaarge room, many masks - no problem). Other possible candidates won´t leave their positions (von der Leyen with the EU and Söder as leader of CSU (although he could become Chancellor later)). This one is much clearer than most people here believe. No big change.  https://www.manager-magazin.de/politik/deutschland/cdu-vorsitz-und-kanzlerkandidatur-armin-laschet-und-jens-spahn-weit-vor-friedrich-merz-a-1305964.html
A lot can happen as the world rethinks what it needs in leadership over the next 9 months.
No change this week, so forecast remains same Still ignoring cancellation
Come 2H2020 the only thing on people's minds will be the economy as it will be in shamb les everywhere.

One addition to my last comment: about Merz it´s not just about being better able to cooperate with the left-wing green Party. The congress will be held by delegates, not ordinary party members. They will decide on a basis that helps them keep their personal power. Under Merkel the CDU for several reasons in many aspects turned towards left-wing/green politics (they strategically had to, to be precise). Many of the parties voters consider that good, others don´t (I don´t!). Merz would lead the party back to a more conservative track. That might get some voters back from AfD, but more could be lost to SPD or the green Party, so in the end it could be bad for overall results in elections. That´s a relevant strategic point, and even I would consider it more valid than having my personal favourite candidate Merz as the new party leader. A good compromise from a delegate´s point of view will be the team of Laschet (moderate boss) and Spahn (conservative deputy).
As said before: I´m not neutral in this question, but you won´t get deeper insight on it elsewhere.
Hattip @pstamp for insights into this most important political event. With so many changes possible I have emphsized the wild card.

There is not going to be a special congress before January 21 2021 and
the successor is not listed
Its Ursula
What do you think @tsm
Not an expert on German politics but going to use this to test a theory, ignoring cancellation as that is virus related  Theory is number of Twitter followers

First to mention: I´m german, and the CDU is my favourite party, so i´m not really neutral in this topic.
Some things to consider: the congress is postponed to "as soon as the epidemic allows". That could be in a few weeks, but definitely will take place long before 1 Jan 21, and it won´t be cancelled, because the party needs a new leader after Kramp-Karrenbauer gave up.
About the candidates: Merz is my favourite, and for most in the CDU too. He´s a selfmade-millionaire top lawyer and manager for Blackrock and an old enemy of Merkel (a rival she got rid of long ago, so he just decided to make lots of money in between). The party leadership and most likely most of the delegates in the congress prefer Laschet, because with him cooperation with the left-wing green party would be much easier (and cooperation with them is necessary for several relevant reasons). Röttgen is brilliant and would be a great choice, but he is the "outsider" here, without any real backing by relevant groups. Much more important is "someone else": Health Minister Spahn could decide to go for it himself instead of just backing up Laschet. He is conservative but not the green partie´s "declared enemy" like Merz and ist just gaining lots of reputation for his cool management of the corona crisis. I don´t think, that he will do it now, because he is young and can wait for a better chance. As "wingman" of Laschet their chances together are higher than those of Merz alone.

As i think it is unlikely that there will be no decision this year as, because then the CDU would be without a Leader for about a year.
I also think it is unlikely that there will be more candidates in the race, as the current persons embody the two political trends in the CDU. Also they are already endorsed by the two big strongholds of the CDU in Germany, NRW and BW, so even if there is another candidate, he is unlikely to win.
I expect a close race between Merz and Laschet with a slight higher probability for Merz. I consider him more competent (can be important as the leader of the CDU is a likely candidate for competing as Bundeskanzler) and most of the CDU members favour him (attention has to be paid to the mechansim for the election: the leader is voted by delegates, not by ordinary members).

I'll follow the lead of @sebawi who has boots on the ground, while I just have my head in the sand. Doubtful this event can be held until Fall/Winter and lot can change in that timeframe. We'll all be wiser for the experience.

I am not German and cannot judge poltical events for Germans, But whoever succeeds Merkel, rather they take over after a crisis. In fact this crisis is as challenging as a war, Requires intense mobilization of public opinion, sealing the borders, readying for big German budget deficit of almost $600-billion.
At this moment with Italy teetering and the events in UK and with UK in question and US, somebody has to manage the  special relationship until Trump gives way, This requires the preparation for transition to power after the US inauguration. If Biden comes through then Merkel gets one last ticker tape parade. Quite a string of great ChANCELLORS   See

They ruled Germany
Seven Chancellors and one Chancellor have led Germany's fortunes since 1949 . Profiles of the heads of government who shaped the Federal Republic.
Whoever succeeds her would probably prefer to start on a new slate.
Merkel has managed one crisis after another succesfully. Same with Macron If Germany has good outcome from virus as with France Merkel and Macron will shine again for a while. Indian Summer. Compare for example Italy and US.

I honestly haven't the faintest idea. I was 100% into it being cancelled (due to coronavirus). But now gjopen have extended the question until the end of the year. Is there really any difference between a cancellation and a lengthy postponement? Of course at some point in the future the CDU will have to select a new leader...

Difficult to answer when the goal post has been moved. Its a long time to Dec 31. Some listed may not even stand.
At this point peanut butter is the only forecast worth making.
Merkel is key right now.no one else matters until next year.

Since the timeline extension of this question is until the end of the year, I'm assuming the special party congress will be held sometime this year, and the results of this congress will answer this question.
for the next weeks oder months, the discussion ist suspended for the time after corona

Strictly based on the question and responses at hand, congress has been postponed and a successor cannot be chosen. However, we can look at the possibilities of ignoring the cancellation. I believe Armin Laschet is the most likely to succeed Angela Merkel because he takes the moderate tone of Merkel. This comes down to an issue of whether the CDU wants to take a more conservative or more moderate tone. The move to ally with the AfD showed huge repercussions and it would be hard to see a conservative candidate be able to establish a majority in German politics. Laschet would be most likely because he takes a moderate tone in the face of the growing appeal of the green party.  https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/03/09/armin-laschet-merkels-pro-russia-china-friendly-successor/
https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2020/03/12/world/europe/12reuters-health-coronavirus-germany-cdu.html

Friedrich Merz has been tested positive to coronavirus. Most probably, the party congress will not take place.

Merkel in control no consensus successor in party. Merkel may stay another year or two. With its borders closed one only Hope's Germany and California economic power houses have universal health care with one of the best private university and public university hospitals.
So Merkel stays for now.

Merz has the highest support by opinion polls, Laschet has been support by less number of people and Röttgen shows the lowest number of supporters. I think Merz has higher skills than Merkel on understanding the baseline of constitution of Germany, its system of values, and can better interpret law in general. Merz understands economics better because he is business lawyer. Merz is better connected nationally and internationally to individuals of high respect at business and other areas as his competitors. Merz is my favorite and I want that he should be elected as CDU party chairman and I think he should be also elected as next chancellor of Germany. I have a bias in my forecast due to my opinions.

Germany: the governing centre-right CDU (EPP) cancels its leadership election—planned for late April—due to the Coronavirus. Kramp-Karrenbauer earlier said in February that she'd be stepping down from the party leadership. She will now remain CDU's leader until further notice.
